name: Avery Hodges
comment info:
I notice that anxiety and depression seem to be the biggest problem among teenagers. I would assume it's the pressure put on them by the school system, on top of everything else they deal with. That may not be the case, but that's what makes the most sense to me.

I also realize teen pregnancy seems to be pretty low on the chain, and that is probably due to the amount of time spent teaching children how big of an issue it is and how to prevent it.

Also, I believe that a lot of these issues could be tied to one another, leading from one issue into the next. Say someone is being bullied, given that it's the second biggest problem on this list. That bullying leads to depression. Depression could lead to substance abuse, such as drinking and doing drugs.

I feel like if we can do our best to help prevent and create solutions to some of these issues, it will create a domino effect that will help to decrease others as well.

name: Jayden
comment info: Regarding this graph, I noticed that significant issues such as Anxiety & Depression, and Bullying are major worries for U.S. teenagers from ages 13-17. Here in Canada, teens would have similar concerns. As a 13 year-old, Drug addiction and Drinking alcohol are not concerns my age group, yet 50% of the people surveyed believed it was. I am curious as to why these two options are included in this graph because the age group surveyed are not legally allowed to drink or use these substances. I also wonder why Bullying isn't at the top of this graph because many of these issues can be contributed by bullying. Another thought I had was that some of these topics are vague, such as Anxiety, Depression, and Bullying, as they could be more specific. For example, Anxiety and Depression can be caused by the lack of socializing due to the overuse of social media and video games. Bullying can be separated into cyber, verbal, physical or racism because each has its own effects. I believe a catchy headline for this graph would be, "Bullying has Become a Major Teenage Problem." I think this is a good topic because in the past, while the other options were already big concerns, bullying wasn't recognized until a few years ago.
